text: hi everyone Anthony Fantana here
Internet's busiest music nerd and in
this video I'm going to review the new
have a nice life record the unnatural
world have a nice life is a Connecticut
basic music duo featuring Dan Barrett
and Timucua they have been active on and
off since 2000 and their music has
earned this incredibly passionate cult
following that's slowly been growing
since 2008 that's when the duo dropped
their 85-minute powerhouse of a double
album death consciousness it is not a
record that made a huge splash initially
but it is still a sonic Titan that
thinks nothing of violently slashing
apart drone noise post-punk industrial
rock and shoegaze and then reassembling
them into an uncompromising lead Ark set
of songs with pretty tongue-in-cheek
song titles a quick one before the
eternal worm devours Connecticut waiting
for black metal records to come in the
mail to me track titles like this are a
bit of an emotional defense mechanism of
sorts after exercising songs that have
so many legitimately tortured moments in
them I imagine that the first thing you
want to do is kind of shrug it off but
even though Dan and Tim moved on past
this record artistically through other
collaborative projects and bands and
solo efforts it is death consciousness
that has continued to be their most
popular record to date I can only
imagine following this record up could
be a really daunting task could be
really intense but at least for me
personally the pressure isn't so immense
considering that I've been tuning into a
lot of these other projects that the Dan
and Tim have been involved in and to me
a lot of these projects carry a lot of
similarities to have a nice life the
darkness the lo-fi recordings the
dissonance and plus there's all the
bands that Dan supports through his
record label enemies list home
recordings and even though he doesn't
involve himself in any of these projects
I believe artistically a lot of the
bands that he puts out sort of seemed to
be musical kindred spirits in a way
abusing noise and reverb and genre
boundaries and their releases as well
and that joyous tradition
continues on to this new have a nice
life record as well an LP that is
noticeably shorter than its predecessor
about 40 minutes shorter which is a bit
of a disappointment at first glance but
I do think Dan and Tim have pulled
together a sonically mature record with
the unnatural world putting out some of
their most vivid and dismal sounds yet
the songs on this record have a loud
booming depressive impact yet so many of
the details are smudged obscured and
purposefully hidden by loads of effects
and really weird mixing practices think
the microphones Mount Erie record but
with a goth rock obsession and way less
disregard for readability for me this is
lo-fi indie rock that was written for
the end of the world and has the
oppressive volume of a doom metal record
and this heaviness swallows the songs
that have a nice life creates it's like
they're trying to drown out their own
self created musical apocalypse if
there's anything that's sort of a
positive of the unnatural world just
being about 48 minutes it is that it
makes have a nice life a little more
digestible this time around and I feel
like this record is more focused as well
the songs here tend to range from really
noisy post-punk barnburners to
incredibly droney ballads and I think
have a nice life has success on both
sides of the spectrum one of my favorite
hard-hitting tracks off of this LP
defenestration song as this driving
distorted bass line cavernous drums and
just a really thick cocoon of tones and
noises surrounding all of it
the vocals are tucked away in this haze
of sound but it makes the melodies that
they're singing no less catchy and their
passion still rings through as well as
you're getting these really fiery
screams and shouts coming out of the
background I just love the growing sea
of dissonance on this track as it
progresses I really dig the track dan
and Tim reunited by fate as well the
song is cut from the same dismal
post-punk cloth and has this bassline
that doesn't feel like it would be out
of place in some kind of 90s alternative
rock tune the track starts off with a
great groove but in
Stanly the song is smothered in this
really warped wall of tones that I just
cannot describe is it synthesizers is it
guitars I have really no idea all I know
is that the explosion of this sound is
so just sudden that it feels like being
plunged into a frigid pool of water
I love the dismal guitar interlude in
the second half of this track and the
song slowly just depletes in sound and
just sort of gives up on itself by the
end not in a disappointing way but in a
way that sort of reflects the depression
that is so palpable in most of these
tracks then there's the track unholy
life another more upbeat hard-hitting
rhythmic song on this album but one of
the most emotionally neutral tracks as
well with this sort of strung out twangy
guitar line that kicks the track off
that sounds somewhat like a Beach fossil
song I think the only thing keeping this
track from being a Beach fossil song is
how it grows so noisy and dissonant as
it moves along a lot like the track
defenestration song which to me is so
Joy Division so Bauhaus but to me that
track is long enough the melody is
catchy enough for me to just okay this
is a this is a unique atmosphere this is
an interesting song unholy life however
is just way too short of breath for me
to be impressed with it as its own sort
of composition it feels like a bit of a
cliffhanger to me and unfortunately
there are other songs on here that do
give us somewhat similar vibe as well
songs that build things to a really
impressive crescendo or have a great
sound but sort of fizzle out into a
really unimpressive close for one the
track burial Society which I love up
until the mid point where we're getting
all these falsetto which really take me
out of the mood of the song
unfortunately and after these vocals
come and leave the songs coast downward
is is pretty underwhelming and the track
music will on tune the sky to some
really beautiful droning guitars on this
track with some soaring vocals over them
and it's it's really a blissful moment
on this album that is a bit of a breath
of fresh air from all the darkness I
love the guitar tone I love the ringing
bells on this track but I wish it went
more
places compositionally there were tracks
that I really did love on the drone e'er
side of this record though like
Guggenheim Wax Museum the intro of this
album and the last song to Guggenheim is
one of the most powerful crescendos on
this entire album I love the blaring
guitar solo toward the finish - and the
song works really effectively as an
introduction to this LP as well and
glides into the next song very nicely
and the closing track on here really one
of the most dynamic songs on this entire
album the longest song on this entire
album - takes its time growing a mood
growing the drone building the tension
it really puts me into an emotional
state before it floats away into the
abyss assist and I've got to mention the
song corpsey as well another track that
does a great job of taking its time to
set a mood starts things off with some
really depressing vocal cuts of an
interview with a child who was living at
Pennhurst asylum and sort of talking
about why he was being punished there
and whether or not he liked it there and
so on and so forth and I love the guitar
riffs on this track and how they switch
back and forth between this loud and
louder sounds I just wish a natural
world dabbled in dynamic tracks like
this just a little bit more still
despite that complaint I did end up
loving a majority of the tracks on here
but part of me does wish that there was
a massive timespan to this record to
match the massive sounds and massive
emotions I do have some love for this
LPM feeling a strong 7 to like 8 on this
record transition if you've given this
record to listen what did you think of
it did you love it
did you hate it why and what do you
think I should review next man for the
love of for the love of God have a nice
life the unnatural world forever
